title: ST558 Homework 4
text:
../MyData.csv
It creates a single place to access different files like datasets and quarto files so the user can quickly navigate between them when working on a project. It also has version control integration which allows multiple people to work together on the same project.
Git is a version control software that tracks the changes made to files allowing users easy access to previous versions of their work. It also allows for multiple users to work together and combine their coding efforts. Github is a platform that can be used for creating Git repositories and acts as a place for users to easily access and keep track of the changes recorded by Git.
The first difference is that the default printing method of tibble provides information on the numbers of observations, the columns, and will only print the first few rows/columns to avoid clutter. The second difference is that tibbles do not coerce down to a vector when subsetting to only one column using square brackets ‘[]’
as_tibble |> select(starts_with(“Petal), Species) |> filter(Petal.Length < 1.55) |> arrange(Species)

It also allows for multiple users to work together and combine their coding efforts. Github is a platform that can be used for creating Git repositories and acts as a place for users to easily access and keep track of the changes recorded by Git.
The first difference is that the default printing method of tibble provides information on the numbers of observations, the columns, and will only print the first few rows/columns to avoid clutter. The second difference is that tibbles do not coerce down to a vector when subsetting to only one column using square brackets ‘[]’

title: ST558 Homework 4
text:
Task 2
Reading in the glass data

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

glass_names <- c("Id", "RI", "Na", "Mg", "Al", "Si", "K", "Ca", "Ba", "Fe", "Type_of_glass")
glass <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/glass.data", col_names = glass_names)

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, Type_of_glass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glass

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0                1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0                1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0                1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0                1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0                1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26             1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0                1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0                1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0                1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11             1
# ℹ 204 more rows


Manipulating the glass data

glass |>
  mutate(Type_of_glass = ifelse(Type_of_glass == 1, "building_windows_float_processed",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 2, "building_windows_non_float_processed",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 3, "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 4, "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 5, "containers",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 6, "tableware",
                         ifelse(Type_of_glass == 7, "headlamps",
                                NA)))))))
         ) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2, Type_of_glass %in% c("tableware","headlamps"))

# A tibble: 38 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        
 1   177  1.52  14    2.39  1.56  72.4  0     9.57  0        0 tableware    
 2   178  1.52  13.8  2.41  1.19  72.8  0     9.77  0        0 tableware    
 3   179  1.52  14.5  2.24  1.62  72.4  0     9.26  0        0 tableware    
 4   180  1.52  14.1  2.19  1.66  72.7  0     9.32  0        0 tableware    
 5   181  1.51  14.4  1.74  1.54  74.6  0     7.59  0        0 tableware    
 6   182  1.52  15.0  0.78  1.74  72.5  0     9.95  0        0 tableware    
 7   183  1.52  14.2  0     2.09  72.7  0    10.9   0        0 tableware    
 8   184  1.52  14.6  0     0.56  73.5  0    11.2   0        0 tableware    
 9   185  1.51  17.4  0     0.34  75.4  0     6.65  0        0 tableware    
10   186  1.51  13.7  3.2   1.81  72.8  1.76  5.43  1.19     0 headlamps    
# ℹ 28 more rows


Reading in the yeast data

yeast_names <- c("seq_name", "mcg", "gvh", "alm", "mit", "erl", "pox", "vac", "nuc", "class")
yeast <- read_fwf("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/yeast.data",
         fwf_widths(c(12, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 3), yeast_names))

Rows: 1484 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

chr (2): seq_name, class
dbl (8): mcg, gvh, alm, mit, erl, pox, vac, nuc

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

yeast

# A tibble: 1,484 × 10
   seq_name     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac   nuc class
   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
 1 ADT1_YEAST  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 2 ADT2_YEAST  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 3 ADT3_YEAST  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 4 AAR2_YEAST  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54  0.22 NUC  
 5 AATM_YEAST  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 6 AATC_YEAST  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49  0.22 CYT  
 7 ABC1_YEAST  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 8 BAF1_YEAST  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58  0.34 NUC  
 9 ABF2_YEAST  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49  0.22 MIT  
10 ABP1_YEAST  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58  0.3  CYT  
# ℹ 1,474 more rows


Manipulating the yeast data

yeast |>
  select(mcg:vac, class) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), 
                list(mean = mean, median = median), 
                .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"))

# A tibble: 1,484 × 22
# Groups:   class [10]

title: ST558 Homework 4
text:
Task 3
Reading in white wine data

library(readxl)
white_wine <- read_excel("white-wine.xlsx")
white_wine

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 7              62               0.32          0.16              7       0.045
 8               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 9              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Changing variable names

wine_names <- read_excel("white-wine.xlsx", sheet = excel_sheets("white-wine.xlsx")[2])
colnames(white_wine) <- wine_names[[1]]

Adding a column to the data set

white_wine <- white_wine |>
  mutate(type = "white")

Reading in the red wine data, changing names, and adding column

red_wine <- read_delim("red-wine.csv", delim = ";", skip = 1, col_names = wine_names[[1]])

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed_acidity, volatile_acidity, citric_acid, residual_sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

red_wine <- red_wine |>
  mutate(type = "red")

Combining the data sets

wine <- dplyr::bind_rows(white_wine, red_wine)
wine

# A tibble: 6,497 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 6,487 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Manipulating combined data set

wine |>
  filter(quality > 6.5, alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(across(alcohol, 
                list(mean = mean, sd = sd), 
                .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 8
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality alcohol_mean
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>        <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9        122. 
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124 white       9        122. 
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125 white       9        122. 
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127 white       9        122. 
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129 white       9        122. 
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105 white       8         94.1
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
10            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: alcohol_sd <dbl>
